back_matter.text: Attitudes towards and experience of the menstrual cycle across different cultural and religious groups Rosalind S. Bramwell, Rabia Zeb University of Liverpool, Liverpool, United Kingdom, e-mail: rosb@liv.ac.uk Literature References: Brooks-Gunn, J., Ruble, D. N. (1980) Objectives: At the conclusion of this paper, delegates will be aware of the impact of culture on attitudes towards and experience of menstruation, and on the inter-relationship of attitudes and experience. They will be aware of the implications of this research for our understanding of menstrual cycle distress as a physiological versus socio-cultural phenomena, and the possible implications for other aspects of mental and physical well-being. The distinction between ethnicity and cultural group will also be explored.Abstract: Purpose: To explore differences in attitudes towards and experience of, and the different inter-relationships between attitude and experience, in different cultural groups.Methods: Materials: The Menstrual Distress Questionnaire (Moos, 1968), Menstrual Attitude Questionnaire (Brooks-Gunn and Ruble, 1980) and a sociodemographic questionnaire, available in English and Urdu and in written and audio formats. Participants were recruited to three groups according to family religion: 48 Muslims, 46 Hindus, 76 Christians. Hindu and Muslim participants were almost exclusively of Asian ethnic origin, whilst Christian respondents were 'white' British.Results: Showed significant between-group attitudes in attitudes but also experience. Briefly, the Hindu and Christian groups were found to be at opposite ends of a continuum of attitudes and experience and the Muslim group to fall somewhere in the middle. A similar trend was found for the relationships between attitudes and menstrual distress.

Conclusions: This research confirmed the role of cultural attitudes in experiences of menstrual distress, which presents a challenge to purely medical models. Ethnic origin is often seen as an important predictor of attitudes and of the ways in which well-being and distress may be expressed. This study highlighted that family religion, a 'cultural' rather than 'ethnic' difference, can be more relevant. Literature References: Gross, K., Wells, C., Radigan-Garcia, A.,Dietz, P. (2002) . Correlates of self-reports of being very depressed in the months after delivery: Results from the Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System. Maternal and Child Health Journal 6: 247-253. Hobfoll, S., Ritter, C., Lavin, J., Hulsizer, M., Cameron, R. (1995) . Depression prevalence and incidence among inner-city pregnant and postpartum women. Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology 63: 445-453.Objectives: At the conclusion of this presentation the participants should have an increased understanding of the relative significance of SES and ethnicity in postpartum sadness.Abstract: Purpose: The relative significance of SES and ethnicity in predicting the experience of postpartum sadness is examined.Method: Data were obtained from The Iowa Barriers to Prenatal Care Questionnaire, a tool used for surveillance of perinatal experiences in all maternity hospitals in the State of Iowa. The large (n ¼ 25, 116) and demographically representative sample includes women from varying economic and ethnic groups. Low mood was assessed with one item: ''have you felt sad or miserable much of the time over the past two weeks'' which was positively endorsed by 16% of the women.Results: Bivariate analyses revealed that marital status, ethnicity, educational level, and income were associated with the presence of low mood. Hierarchical logistic regression analyses indicated that even after controlling for these other demographic variables, ethnicity was a significant predictor of low mood. Specifically, in comparison to Caucasian mothers, a significantly lower percentage of Asian and Hispanic mothers reported low mood. In contrast a significantly higher percentage of African-American mothers reported low mood as compared to Caucasian mothers.Conclusion: These results suggest that Hispanic and Asian cultures provide protective elements for the mental health of postpartum women and that African-American women are a particularly vulnerable group. Objectives: At the conclusion of this presentation, the participants will:1. be able to identify the diferent components of a model of service that works successfully to treat families with perinatal mood disorders. 2. learn some of the methods of partnership building between community, health and social service agencies.Abstract: Postpartum mood and anxiety disorders affect about 15% of all childbearing women. Similar rates of depression are now being identified during pregnancy. Untreated, it can lead to poor attachment, family breakdown, chronic forms of depression, developmental delays for the child, suicide and infanticide.This paper presents an integrated multidisciplinary model of early intervention, prevention and treatment of perinatal mood disorders. It was developed as a result of participatory research that included clients and the health=social service organizations serving this population in Canada.Key issues, opportunities and challenges emerged. Some of these were: lack of knowledge about perinatal mood disorders on the part of the public and health=social service providers, delayed identification, frustration finding or accessing appropriate care, lack of funding, lack of trust between the various professions involved.This model addresses the issues identified from the research. It has led to better wraparound service, prevented recurrence, reduced suffering and built partnerships between community=health=social service agencies. It has been adopted successfully in urban and rural communities with different multicultural and socio-economic blends.It is the hoped that the participant will learn from our research and take back new ideas to their communities to help families with perinatal mood disorders.The prevention of postnatal depression: a narrative systematic review Objectives: To explore the relation between shift work as stressor and the prevalence of cardiovascular and immunsystem affection.Abstract: The causality between shift work and cardio-vascular dysfunction remains unknown. Accordingly we attempted an approach to explore such association. Electrocardiographic, biochemical and physical data obtained from 61 shift and 18 day workers were assessed to clarify the impact of shift work on cardiovascular system, serum cortisol and salivary IgA levels. Our results suggested an increased risk of cardiovascular morbidity and statistically significantly higher levels of serum cortisol and lower levels of salivary IgA, which are considered as potential biomarkers of stress, among rotatory shift workers compared to the control group. The duration of shift work showed a statistically significant negative correlation with salivary IgA level and a positive one with serum cortisol level.Abstract: This presentation will describe a recently completed treatment development study aimed at adapting Interpersonal Psychotherapy (IPT), an individual treatment found efficacious for the treatment of major depressive disorder, to treat low-income, predominantly minority women with current posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) after interpersonal trauma (e.g., sexual and=or physical assault or abuse, sexual molestation, domestic violence, etc.) in a group format. Subjects were recruited at public sector health and WIC clinics and treatment was provided where women received their usual health care. Forty-eight women were randomized to group IPT or a wait-list control group after assessments using structured diagnostic instruments. Only 5 women randomized to treatment dropped out prematurely. The results showed that women who received IPT for PTSD treatment did significantly better regarding PTSD symptoms and interpersonal functioning than women in the wait-list control group. Abstract: Background: Several sources of heterogeneity in major depression have been identified. These include age of onset, presence of comorbid disorders, and history of childhood sexual abuse. This study examined these factors in the context of the contrast between onset of depression in young women before and after age 16.

Method: Sampling was carried out in two phases. In the first, questionnaires were sent to women aged 25-36 in five primary care practices. Second phase subjects for interview (N ¼ 197) were drawn from three strata defined on the basis of childhood adversities. Interviews conducted and rated independently assessed, a) recalled childhood experiences, psychopathology and parental psychiatric disorder, and b) adult personality functioning and adult lifetime psychopathology. Frequencies of predictor and response variables, effect estimates and their confidence intervals were weighted back to the general population questionnaire sample.Results: Compared to adult onset depression, juvenile onset adult depression was associated with comorbid childhood psychopathology and peer problems, poor parental care and child sexual abuse involving actual or attempted intercourse; those with juvenile onset depression were more likely to have a teenage pregnancy, and as adults they had higher levels of comorbid psychiatric disorders, and personality dysfunction. The adult onset depression group was characterised by a history of contact child sexual abuse without actual or attempted intercourse, and to a lesser extent, poor parental care. Juvenile onset depression was associated with a parental history of alcohol problems, and adult onset with a history of depression in parents.Conclusions: Although the childhood data in this study were based on retrospective reports, they were consistent with findings from prospective studies. They add to the evidence that juvenile and adult onset depression in adult life probably arise from different developmental pathways and causal processes. Juvenile onset depression appears to be a component of a broad set of emotional and behavioural problems, and social impairment starting in early childhood, in which the causal processes involve an interaction between Objectives: At the concludion of this presentation the participants should be able to recognize gender differences in Pathological Gambling, understand the concept of telescoping effect as well as ots consequences in female gamblers.Abstract: More women are having gambling problems, similar to alcohol and drug addiction. This can be related to: new gambling venues with increased access for women, women gambling to escape from problems, and a faster progression (telescoping effect-T.E.) of social to pathological gambling (PG) in women. Though T.E. has been identified in different studies, little has been done to investigate its causes. This study investigates gender differences that might explain T.E. and that can be important for prevention and treatment strategies of PG, comparing 78 male and 78 female gamblers in: sociodemographic characteristics, clinical features, psychiatric comorbidities, and risk-taking behaviors. Pathological gamblers were diagnosed through the SOGS and the DSM-IV criteria; the SCAN was used to investigate psychiatric comorbidity; the TCI, and the BIS were used to investigate personality features. More females are single; females start and have gambling problems later in life than males. More females prefer electronic games and gamble to escape from problems. Males have more alcohol abuse=dependence, while females have more of depression. Besides gender, starting to gamble later in life and preference for electronic games, are responsible for T.E. in PG. We conclude that gender should be considered in prevention and treatment strategies for PG. Abstract: Although at least one-third of problem=pathological gamblers are women, the majority of the scant literature available on treatment and recovery is derived from males. Recent gender comparisons find significant differences between men and women who have sought help for problems associated with their gambling, which raises the possibility of different treatment=recovery processes. However, the recovery process for women, particularly in non-clinical samples, is not well understood or documented. This study attempts to remedy this situation by reporting on the nature of formal and informal supports for a non clinical group of women who have achieved at least six months of abstinence from compulsive gambling (N ¼ 136). Data was gathered from a 79 item online survey that was linked to various national and state problem gambling councils. The analyses indicate the respondents were primarily middle-aged, middle class, welleducated white women with a serious gambling problem of either slot machines or video poker. The majority of the women received either Gamblers Anonymous (GA) or professional help, and 20% were recovering ''on their own.'' Gender related barriers to GA attendance and professional help were reported. However, most women indicated the reputation of GA as a ''male preserve'' needs changing. After GA, informal support systems (spou-se=partner, friends, children) were most critical for recovery, although not without problems. Professional helpers were the least important. Objectives: Participants will be familiar with the efficacy of primary prevention for postpartum depression based on research findings to date, as well as methodological concerns in the area of prevention research, such as identification of high risk women, protocol adherence, use of adequate sample sizes, and the need for cost-benefit analyses.Abstract: Purpose: Postpartum depression is a major complication following childbirth (WHO), interfering significantly with daily functioning and resulting in adverse consequences in the child. Because the event of childbirth is largely predictable, primary prevention appears to be a reasonable undertaking. The purpose of this study was to examine the efficacy of a preventive intervention adapted from Interpersonal Psychotherapy (P-IPT) for women at high risk for postpartum depression.Methods: Forty-five high risk women were randomized to Preventive IPT (P-IPT) (n ¼ 24) or a no treatment control group (n ¼ 21). P-IPT consisted of five individual sessions, beginning in pregnancy and ending at one month postpartum. Assessments were conducted initially and at one and six months postpartum.Results: Women receiving P-IPT evidenced significantly lower rates of postpartum depression compared to women in the control group (0% vs. 25%) at one month postpartum. However, prophylactic effects were not maintained through six months postpartum. There were no significant differences between groups on self-report measures of depressive symptomatology, general psychiatric symptomatology, marital satisfaction, or general postpartum social adjustment.Conclusions: P-IPT had positive, but limited, prophylactic effects through one month postpartum. Methodological limitations and other important issues in the area of prevention research warrant further investigation. Objectives: At the conclusion of this presentation participants should be able to recognize the factors that may influence impoverished women's ability and=or willingness to access mental health services during pregnancy.

Abstract: Purpose: It has been estimated that up to 30% of pregnant women experience depressive symptoms that interfere with their ability to function. A significant number of these women, particularly those of low socioeconomic status, do not receive treatment for their mental health difficulties. This paper describes qualitative data regarding treatment accessibility, and the willingness of indigent women to access available treatments for depression during pregnancy.Methods: Qualitative data was obtained from focus groups with pregnant women recruited from an OB-GYN clinic and five Maternal Health Care Centers (MHC) serving low-income women, and from discussions with staff members at these MHC's. Additionally, a self-report questionnaire regarding access to mental health treatment was administered to 1020 pregnant women at these sites.Results: The most compelling finding from these data is that women often avoid seeking services because they perceive the care available to them to be of low quality. Financial barriers and the stigma associated with mental health care are also barriers to seeking care for these women.Conclusions: Poor women are at high risk for depression yet have the most difficulty accessing care. This research presents the voices of these women and provides insight into how to better facilitate mental health treatment for impoverished women. Objectives: The participants will be able to:1. identify 4 ways in which trauma-informed treatment services improve outcomes for women with co-occurring disorders 2. list at least 3 clinical, evidence-based interventions for treating women with co-occurring disorders and their children 3. be able to differentiate between treatment-as-usual versus integrated treatment servicesAbstract: Historically, individuals who had co-occurring disorders of substance abuse, mental illness, and histories of violence were provided treatment sequentially to treat each disorder separately. A five-year, national, cross-site research project, the ''Women, Co-Occurring Disorders and Violence Study,'' funded by the Substance Abuse Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA), examined outcomes for women and their children who were treated simultaneously for their co-occurring disorders. A trauma-informed series of treatment protocol, clinical interventions, and service and systems integration was developed and measured. Preliminary data suggests that trauma-informed, integrated treatment services yield better outcomes for women with co-occurring disorders and their children. This presentation will discuss lessons learned from the project, as well as highlight evidence-based curricula and innovative practices developed and implemented as part of the study. Objectives: The participant will be able to:
back_matter.section: Access to mental health care services for low-income pregnant women

back_matter.text: 1. give 3 methods for integrating consumer=sur vivor=recovering individuals into existing systems 2. demonstrate an understanding of the need for service and system integration as part of developing effective client treatment and subsequent health policy Abstract: This presentation will discuss the role of the consumer= survivor=recovering (CSR) staff persons in an agency, and the importance of incorporating CSRs into every level of service and systems integration. According to Weissman and Brown (1995) , ''In addition to being able to establish rapport and gain access, there is every indication that 'natural' or 'indigenous' leaders can themselves be an intervention, by serving as a positive role model and believable message bearers.'' Lessons learned from the inclusion of CSRs as staff at all levels of SAMHSA's five-year, national research project, ''Women, Co-Occurring Disorders, and Violence Study'' will be discussed.

Norma Finkelstein, Institute for Health and Recovery, Cambridge, MA, U.S.A., e-mail: Normafinkelstein@healthrecovery.org Literature References: Barreira, P., Espey, B., Fishbein, R., Moran, D., Flannery, R.B. Jr. (2000) . Linking substance abuse and serious mental illness service delivery systems: Initiating a statewide collaboration. The Journal of Behavioral Health Services and Research. Finkelstein, N. (1996) . Using the Relational Model as a Context for Treating Pregnant and Parenting Chemically Dependent Women. Journal of Chemical Dependency Treatment 6: 23-44.Abstract: This presentation will describe and illustrate the strategies of relational systems change using the WELL Project, one of the sites of SAMHSA's Women, Co-Occurring Disorders and Violence Study, as a case study. Relational systems change does not focus on relationships or systems but encompasses both. Systems are made up of people, who grow and change in the context of connections to others. Relational systems work creates environments that encourage, facilitate and inspire people to engage in change. Relational systems change strategies include building relationships and creating linkages, creating a safe environment, involving consumers, a collaborative approach, values clarification, ongoing support for change and working at multiple levels. The use of these strategies by the WELL Project at the local, community and state levels to move the service system in the direction of providing trauma informed, integrated care will be described. Systems changes that occurred as a result, including increased awareness of the impact of violence on women with mental health and substance abuse disorders, increased availability of trauma-specific services, and increased collaboration among state agencies to address these issues, will be discussed. The presentation will conclude that relational systems change is an effective way to promote change in service delivery systems. Objectives: Participants will be able to:
back_matter.section: Relational systems change: an approach to services integration for women

back_matter.text: 1. identify 2-4 group interventions working with women trauma survivors, substance abuse histories, and psychiatric diagnoses 2. describe 4 strategies for services integration 3. demonstrate understanding of the value of peer-run and peer-driven services and supports.Abstract: This presentation will describe 2 of the 9 sites in the SAMHSA-funded ''Women, Co-Occurring Disorders and Violence Study'' that provided services for women trauma survivors and their children. Stra-tegies for service integration (the integration of substance abuse, mental health, and trauma services) in both a rural and an urban setting, as well as the benefits of a program developed, written, evaluated, and administered by women trauma survivors, will be discussed. This presentation will highlight how similar programs can be implemented throughout the country, using a community development approach that utilizes existing resources and natural helping networks.An intervention for children of parents with co-occurring substance abuse and mental health disorders who are victims of violence Nancy VanDeMark, Arapahoe House, Inc., Thornton, CO, U.S.A., e-mail: nancyv@ahinc.org Objectives:1. Participants will be able to identify four challenges to implementation of services for children affected by parental substance abuse, mental illness, and violence. 2. Participants will gain an understanding of the key components of an intervention for children affected by parental substance abuse, mental illness and violence.Abstract: Purpose: Children of parents with co-occurring substance abuse and mental health disorders and histories of violence=trauma have been overlooked in behavioral health treatment systems. The Women, Co-Occurring Disorders and Violence study was a five-year initiative funded by the United States Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) and included a Children's Subset Study that implemented and evaluated an integrated intervention for children of women facing these multiple challenges.Method: The intervention developed and implemented under this study included: (1) a clinical assessment of the child; (2) resource coordination and advocacy; and (3) a twelve session skills building group.Results: The collaborating study sites generated a number of lessons learned related to the design and implementation of interventions for this population. Issues of treatment engagement and retention, cross systems relationships and operational issues offered challenges to implementation and provided valuable insights for other researchers, administrators and clinicians.Conclusions: There are a number of challenges inherent in designing and implementing interventions for children from families affected by substance abuse mental illness and violence. Many of these challenges can be mediated through careful planning and implementation.
